newsitem.title: CANADA: CWB crop tour sees western Prairies drought stress.
newsitem.headline: CWB crop tour sees western Prairies drought stress.

text.p: Drought stress affected fields in all parts of southern and central Alberta and western Saskatchewan, participants of a Canadian Wheat Board crop tour found this week.

"Lack of moisture is the main concern through nearly all locations of this region. The western edge of Alberta is the only exception," CWB weather and crop surveillance director Paul Bullock said in a release.
"In all other locations, there is evidence of moisture stress including 'burned' or whitened heads, aborted florets and wilting," Bullock said.
But yield estimates were higher in southern Alberta compared to last year when drought stress was a bigger problem, Bullock said.
Central Alberta's yield prospects, however, were "significantly" lower than a year ago. The region will have below average crop yields despite good crops along the western edge of the region.

Yields in western Saskatchewan were also seen down from similar estimates done in 1996. Yield potential declined as dry conditions continued and hot, windy weather accelerated the process, Bullock added.
Rain in the next seven to 10 days could prevent further yield deterioration but there has already been significant permanent yield loss, Bullock said.
Participants of the CWB crop tour which began Monday, travel across the Prairies in an effort to assess the condition of crops. The tour concludes August 8.
